thread.title: Many residents yet to return home in fire-ravaged NSW central west
thread.title_full: Many residents yet to return home in fire-ravaged NSW central west

title: Many residents yet to return home in fire-ravaged NSW central west
text:
Map: NSW 
Many residents forced to flee their homes because of a huge bushfire in central western New South Wales are yet to return, a local mayor says, while insurance assessors begin to count the cost of the blazes which have raged across the state. 
The fire, which has already burned through 52,000 hectares, is burning to the east of Dunedoo and is moving north-east towards Leadville, Coolah and Cassilis. 
Overnight Rural Fire Service (RFS) crews took advantage of easing conditions to put out areas of active fire and mop up along the fire's southern edge. 
The RFS has confirmed 30 homes have been destroyed so far across New South Wales. 
Twenty-three of them were destroyed in the fire burning in the central west. Photo: Homes have been reduced to rubble in Uarbry, east of Dunedoo. (ABC News: Jessica Kidd) 
Warrumbungle mayor Peter Shintin said most residents have not yet been allowed to return because of safety concerns. 
"The fire ground is active and there are vehicles people zooming all over the place to put spot fires out and black out areas that are still burning. 
"But as fast as we can the area will be open and as soon as they're open people can start to move around again but it's not a good situation at the moment," he said. 
The number of homes lost was expected to climb, he said. 
The fire-ravaged area also faces another challenge. 
"The biggest problem in the area is that it's old housing and old sheds probably full of fibro sheeting so now we've got the asbestos problem … [so] unless people take special precautions you can't let them go back." Photo: The small town of Uarbry was destroyed. (ABC News: Jessica Kidd) 
There are fears there could be thousands of stock losses. 
Department of Primary Industries state emergency coordinator Simon Oliver said the charred landscape made it difficult to determine the full numbers. 
"We're hoping that it is anecdotal," he said. Locations of destroyed houses: Sir Ivan Fire (Warrumbungle including Uarbry) – 23 homes destroyed (50 per cent of area assessed) Pappinbarra Fire (Port Macquarie-Hastings) - 4 homes destroyed Spring Hill Road, Dondingalong Fire (Kempsey) - 2 homes destroyed (one habitable) Binalong Road, Boggabri (Narrabri) - 1 home destroyed 
"We sometimes hear this with the fires and in a lot of cases stock that are sort of written off are actually found. 
"So we're just hoping that as we get further afield through the fire zone that we actually find that there's been some good stories about survival and not the other." 
The Insurance Council said while it was still too early to assess the full extent of fire damage, staff were on stand-by to handle claims in the central west. 
The council's Campbell Fuller said people should take photos of damaged property when it was safe to do so and speak to insurers before authorising any repairs. 
"The Insurance Council and its members are monitoring the impact of bushfires that are raging right across regional New South Wales," he said. 
"We're sending a staff member to the central west who'll be on deck to help affected policy holders and also liaise with emergency services."
